---
title: 'Student Driven Innovations: A Promised Road to Paideia?'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-52XY26WH" class="csl-bib-container">

Milsom (Eds.), <i>Sustaining the Future of Higher Education</i> (p. 62). Brill Academic Publishers. <a href="https://brill.com/view/title/60562">https://brill.com/view/title/60562</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-52XY26WH" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-52XY26WH" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Stalheim explores how student-driven innovations can help students develop essential skills for the future. By focusing on a case study called the 'Wood Pieces' initiative, the authors show that when students take charge of their learning, they gain valuable abilities like creativity, communication, and critical thinking. These skills are crucial for both personal growth and professional success in a rapidly changing world. The study emphasizes the shift from traditional teaching methods to more interactive, practice-based learning, which better prepares students for sustainable living and working. This research highlights the importance of engaging students in their education to equip them with the tools they need for the 21st century.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-52XY26WH" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Innovative Learning Practices, Professional Development, Work-Based Learning, Student Engagement, Sustainable Skill Development, 21st Century Skills
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-52XY26WH" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    With increased attention on the consideration of innovative learning practices as a  
professional development strategy for preparing students to live and work sustainably in the future,the shift from an instruction paradigm to a learning paradigm has  
acquired its renaissance. This has highlighted the impact of work-based learning, practice, and student engagement on the development of sustainable skill development. 
This chapter investigates the correlation between the concepts of innovation and professional development through an empirical case study. The aim is to uncover  
how student-driven innovations prepare learners for an unknown future and how the ‘Wood Pieces’ initiative supports students’ ‘becoming’. The study confirms the importance of student-driven initiatives as a practical  
method for providing students with 21st century skills, such as creativity, communication and critical thinking; empowering them for a more sustainable personal and  
professional future.
  </article>
